description: From French léproserie and léprosarie, from Medieval Latin leprōsārium, from leprōsus (“leprous”) + -ārium (“-ary: building related to”). Equivalent to leprose +‎ -ery.

entries.meaning: A building used to house lepers, usually in permanent quarantine from the rest of society.
examples: Lewis VIII, king of France, made bequests in the year 1227 to two thousand Leprosaries within his own dominions.
